item.title: Creating an Active Classroom
item.description: Tips for Creating an Active Classroom Make your lectures active, too. It is tempting to equate “active learning” with “group work”, Think about ways to make lectures more active for students. Interject questions (and wait for answers). Mix in short “your turn” exercises or “think-pair-share” questions. Use “call and response”. Ask students to guess computer commands before introducing new commands. Ask lots of questions. But don’t answer them yourself.

item.title: Instructor guide: Center & spread
item.description: Activities Variables and their summary intervals The standard deviation and the summary interval Shapes of distributions The normal distribution Learning objectives Summarize the likely range of a variable using an interval. Choose the summary interval endpoints to include the “vast majority” of the values. Master the convention that “vast majority” is the central 95% of the values. Be able to work with two formats for describing an interval: “A to B” and “C ± D”.

item.title: Instructor Guide: Confidence intervals
item.description: Activities What is a confidence interval? Sampling bias and confidence intervals Comparing two groups Comparing two confidence intervals Two-sample t test Learning objectives connected to confidence intervals Master the relevant vocabulary … population, sample, sample statistic, point estimate, margin of error, confidence interval, confidence level. Recognize the estimation process that leads to a confidence interval: a sample is selected randomly from a population a statistic is calculated from that sample the margin of error and, correspondingly, the confidence interval are calculated from that sample.

item.title: You Want to Know: What's the Point?
item.description: The You Want to Know activity is just one example among many similar activities. This instructors’ activity explores ways you can construct many similar activities for your students. How to make your own activity The key steps to creating these activities are Determine the learning objectives. These might include Making key distinctions like case/variable, categorical/quantitative, explantory/reponse, etc. Identifying key elements of study design. Selecting appropriate analysis methods. Use of software to acheive a task (have students write R command or describe how to use other software) Design the questions.

item.title: Instructor Guide: Introducing the normal distribution
item.description: Activities Distribution shapes Normal parameters Common and rare Learning objectives Understand how a distribution summarizes the properties of a collection of individual values. Be able to translate between major forms of representing distributions graphically, e.g. the density of points in a (jittered) point plot the presentation of such density as a height or width as in a violin or density plot Be able to eyeball the standard deviation of a close-to-normal distribution and, similarly, a 95% summary interval (that is, mean ± two standard deviations ) Be able to identify common characteristics of skew or long-tailed distributions, by comparison to a normal distribution.

item.title: Tips for an active classroom
item.description: Many instructors believe that learning is enhanced in a classroom where students are active participants rather than the passive recipients of a lecture. This document describes some general techniques for fostering an active classroom that can be used in a wide range of lesson topics. (There are also tips for specific topics included in the instructor guide for each topic.) What’s key is to constantly look for opportunities to force students to make a choice, offer a suggestion, or state an interpretation or an opinion.
